<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.

- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.

</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_SocketRecvFrom:
```c
int32 OS_SocketRecvFrom(osal_id_t sock_id, void *buffer, size_t buflen, OS_SockAddr_t *RemoteAddr, int32 timeout)
{
    OS_stream_internal_record_t *stream;
    OS_object_token_t            token;
    int32                        return_code;

    /*
     * Check parameters
     *
     * Note "RemoteAddr" is not checked, because in certain configurations it can be validly null.
     */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(buffer);
    OS_CHECK_SIZE(buflen);

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_REFCOUNT, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, sock_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        stream = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_stream_table, token);

        if (stream->socket_type != OS_SocketType_DATAGRAM)
        {
            return_code = OS_ERR_INCORRECT_OBJ_TYPE;
        }
        else if ((stream->stream_state & OS_STREAM_STATE_BOUND) == 0)
        {
            /* Socket needs to be bound first */
            return_code = OS_ERR_INCORRECT_OBJ_STATE;
        }
        else
        {
            return_code = OS_SocketRecvFrom_Impl(&token, buffer, buflen, RemoteAddr, timeout);
        }

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```

int32 OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, osal_id_t id, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32 return_code;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit(lock_mode, idtype, token);
    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return return_code;
    }

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex(idtype, id, &token->obj_idx);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        token->obj_id = id;

        /*
         * The "ConvertToken" routine will return with the global lock
         * in a state appropriate for returning to the caller, as indicated
         * by the "check_mode" parameter.
         *
         * Note If this operation fails, then it always unlocks the global for
         * all check_mode's other than NONE.
         */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdConvertToken(token);
    }

    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(token);
    }

    return return_code;
}

explanation: I flagged the macro checks and all controlling expressions (the if/else-if conditions) because these are the only places in the function that introduce control flow and so could potentially be invariant (including macros that expand into checks). Other fragments in the function (calls such as OS_ObjectIdGetById, OS_SocketRecvFrom_Impl, OS_ObjectIdRelease, assignments, and the final return) are not controlling expressions and therefore cannot violate Rule 14.3; they depend on runtime values or perform non-control operations and so do not need investigation for invariant controlling expressions.
